Positive Reviews:
I liked the homey atmosphere of the lodge, and that breakfast was included. I liked that it was located right along the Chena River, away from downtown Fairbanks. It was quieter and parking wasn't an issue.
The balcony overlooked the river, so we had a great view. I would go out on the balcony to look up at the sky--it was beautiful! But cold. Super cold.
Most of the staff were friendly, professional, helpful. (There was only one staff member who was just okay, the rest were excellent.)
I loved that they had ice cream for sale in the lobby every night from 6 pm - 9 pm (yes, even in December when the temps were -26!), and it cost only $1 for a generous scoop. They had quite a few flavors to choose from, like maybe ten or twelve. The huckleberry was exceptional!
I appreciated the free airport transfers; the drivers were very friendly, conscientious, and helpful.
Having a refrigerator and a microwave in the room was a big plus in my book. More pluses were the fitness center, the sauna, and the steam room. The patio looked so inviting with nice furniture and gas-fired fire pits but the outdoor temps were just too freakin' cold to sit out there.
Overall, I'm glad we stayed here!

There was a kind of harshly phrased note in the room demanding that you drop off housekeeping tips to the front desk, which I don't like; I mean we always tip, I just don't think I should hand it over to anyone other than the housekeeping staff servicing the room that day; it really made me wonder about the cult thing. Good value; decent free breakfast and free ice cream in the evening. Great location. The bathroom in our room appeared to have been recently renovated and was very clean, and the toiletries were surprisingly good; it also had one of those dreaded wall-mounted blow-dryers but surprisingly an ok one.

The place has gigantic kitsch value, the kind you simply can't fake, though the place sometimes seemed like it was stretching to appear  "in on the joke." There's a LOT of art all over the place (like a LOT....almost too much) and to my surprise most of it was either weird/interesting or actually....good? There's some weird Lynchean/cult-like thing going on with ducks and possibly the staff.  Also the owner of the hotel, a local politician whose search for a Jewish fiancee willing to move to Fairbanks in the 90s made some headlines at the time, was there a lot. There was some quality to the whole place that seemed over-determined, but usually in a beneficial way because this meant that you get a surprisingly good number of amenities at the price point -- a full ironing board and iron; a minifridge, microwave, tea and coffee, mugs, an ice machine, a TV with tons of channels and netflix connectivity, etc. The parking lot was large and we could generally find a spot with an outlet to plug in the car to keep the battery from dying.

The staff was generally quite friendly and helpful, though with that weird Alaska thing going on...you'll know what I mean when you go there. The bartender in the hotel bar told us it was her first day, and we had to give her instructions about how to make all three of the drinks we wanted, and they were not good; however, I have to give her points for her high-effort attempt and can-do attitude (we offered to take simpler drinks, but she insisted on trying).
